[i]Edit[/i]: (8/17/17)
So, I chose to watch a bit of the anime (first 4 episodes), and I think I know what my problem with the VN is. It seems the point at which you branch onto each of the girls' routes is staggered along the common route. Michruru seems to be first, Amane, Makina, Sachi, with Yumiko being last. I chose the LAST route first, which made for a gruling grind through the common route with little action and foreshadowing. The anime also provides several in-the-moment scenes and foreshadowing scenes which hook you far more, and actually make you interested in continuing the journey through the story. It also cuts out several of the scenes from the VN that add no value to plot progression and character development, which made me not want to continue the VN more and more as I progressed. I recommend looking through a guide to see the best way to approach the routes. I'm gonna try out a route that branches earlier, then I will see if this VN deserves an upvote.
[i]Edit[/i]

 
Allow me to begin by saying that this VN is certainly not bad, but not particularly high on my VNs-to-go-down-in-history list. This is where a "Neutral" button for Steam would come into play, but that is fundementally useless. However, I am leaning toward a downvote.

I played down one girl's route, Yumiko's, both good and bad endings, and it wasn't what I expected, in a bad way. For one, the bad ending just abruptly ended. I didn't even know whether I had finished the game or not. Given its rating and some of the clips from the anime that I had seen, I wasn't entirely sure what I expected, but certainly not how it actually played out. How I see it, it's a slice-of-life VN that roles into a more "loose-cannon" type of narrative that gradually tugs at your heart-strings.

Frankly, about the first 25-30 hours, it is just slice-of-life, with very occasional dabblings with some more action-packed scenes. As many have said, it gets more dramatic and emotional once you end up on one of the girls' routes at about the 30-hour mark. However, leading up to that divergence in narrative, there is so much drivel, idle chatter, romantic jokes, and attempts at humor that it gets tiresome extremely quickly. All the while, you are wondering when something of more substance will occur. I get character development, there is plenty of it, but hell they talk for the sake of talking in so many of the early scenes that it seems as if the writers didn't give a lick of consideration for the time-sink and attention readers need to give to these almost meaningless exhalations of air.

The MC, Yuuji, also came off to me as one of those characters who lost everything and ends up developing some sort of dark-humor, sarcastic facade that attempts to cast his past in shadow with an aura of mystery, when all it does is make him look like a juvenile who has yet to find out who he is and what he wants out of life. However, as you get to know him he does become somewhat likeable and endearing, while he also introduces many quotes about life, time, and society that are noteworthy, which I greatly appreciated.

The other characters exhibit your traditional tropes: kuudere, "tsundere," younger-sister figure, older-sister figure, class-rep figure. The roles were carried out flawlessly, but damn the shear amount of annoying interaction between Yuuji and the others was astronomical. Not surprising given the reason why all of them are at Mihama Academy, but it still remains a fact. Michiruru's utterances are faithly annoying throughout the entirety of the common route, aside for one particularly interesting scene. Makina is initially a bit mysterious and intriguing, which quickly falls flat on its face to expose a perturbed being that genuinely becomes somewhat charming with the unique way she talks. But this novelty eventually wears off and becomes more of a nuisance whenever Yuuji interacts with her. Amane, holy hell, the amount of romantic approaches she performs on the Yuuji goes from tantalizing to "Would you give it a break," fairly quickly. Not much to complain about with Sachi. Her devotion is admirable, but once you get familiar with her, the outcome of any interaction with her becomes fairly predictable. Now, Yumiko, my girl of choice, as it were. She is just a mysterious character for the majority of the common route. Interactions with her get extremely predictable after the first two meetings, and again with its equal dose of annoyance with how she tries to circumvent problems. However, things really take a 180 once you reach her route. A turn for the better? Eh, perhaps, but she just really needed to be honest with herself. The shear amount of time she spent denying and apologizing for things amounted to most likely 1/5 of her lines in the entire VN. Got old fast.

The artwork was perfectly acceptable, albeit with a tad low of resolution. A point of note is that some of the scenes had animated background sprites, which were very effective at adding value to the scenes. No complaints on the H-scene front, aside from the requisite comment about censorship, but that is just beating a dead horse. The voices were nothing to write home about. Entirely acceptable.

Overall, really disappointed. From what I have seen from the later VNs in the series it gets pretty interesting, and there looks to be quite a bit more action with the new introductions to the series: Phantom Trigger. However, this first installment of the series has left a sour taste in my mouth, which is a crying shame, because I went into this VN really looking to be whole-heartedly satisfied when I came out on the other side. Suffice it to say that I don't plan on [strike]venturing down the other routes in this VN or[/strike] playing any of the next games in the series anytime soon.

This is one of the best visual novels I have ever experienced. In fact, one of the best reads out there. Second only to Katawa Shoujo, but as in that VN, this has me wishing I could have met the girls when I was in high school. Not sure I would have been as helpful to them as Yuuji, but... I kind of identify with them somewhat.

As you can see by the time I've spent on the game, it took me a while to get through all the routes. Now, the game centers around Kazami Yuuji, a young man with quite the past. One that is barely touched on in most routes, but the broad strokes are that he has been trained from youth an agent for some spy group (which appears to be multinational), and is agent 9029 (which based on how some of the routes mention makes him basically 007 for this organization). He simply wants a normal school experience, and this school, which has five other students, is basically the best choice. He is a second-year student.

As for the girls... I'll mention them in order of my playthrough.

Matsushima Michiru is a second-year student, sporting bleached blond twin-tails, and trying to be a tsundere (though her concept of it is a bit... odd). She is a bit of an idiot, but a well-meaning one. And frankly... she is likely much smarter than she acts. Her route was interesting, and the end of her good route may be the earliest of all of them timewise.

Sakaki Yumiko is a second-year student, and the prodigal daughter of Sakaki Michiaki, who is the President of perhaps the most powerful corporation in Japan. And since she is apparently the only daughter, her route's main issue is Daddy Dearest... Her route was also interesting, and was the first to delve slightly into Yuuji's backstory. The good route, I would say, ends at the second-longest point in time.

Suou Amane is a reddish-haired... well-developed third-year student. She is the most flirtateous with Yuuji, though that is partly due to her backstory. If you go her route, she has (in the words of Lilly from Katawa Shoujo) a "healthy adolescent sex drive".  Her route... man, her route is a tear-jerker. There are many parts of that route that can make you cry, especialy her history... and the end of the good route. Her good route ends at the latest point, by far. [spoiler]All the way to being a grandma.[/spoiler]

Irisu Makina is an innocent and carefree first-year student. She has a bit of a lisp due to events in her past, and is the former successor of the Irisu Clan, which is a very powerful financial clique with holdings worldwide. In fact, they may well rival the Sakaki's East Beach Railway Express Group. She acts as the immature fool. Thing is, she picks up concepts very quickly, so... there may be some of that prodigy she was before the major incident in her past. She calls Yuuji "Onii-chan" at the start, and unless you go into her route, will continue to do so. Considering she technically buys you as her "Papa" if you do go into her route, she is a bit naive at times. Her route is action-packed, and while I'm not sure how I feel about the ending, seems to work. Her bad ending ends six months later, while the good ends a year later. [spoiler]Also noting the change in her condition between both... well, I wonder if that still applied.[/spoiler]

Komine Sachi is a pink-haired (because we need one in any VN, right?) first-year student, who... well, she acts as the maid for the school. Mostly because she cannot turn down a request, and tries to be a "good girl" at all times. While she is safe in the school, this is not so much an issue, but outside of it... this could lead to problems (one of which may have lead to her getting put in the school). She realizes early on that she has history with Yuuji. Her route has the most tear-jerker moments. And the roller-coaster of feeling is a trip, but a cathartic one. Her good ending is probably the second earliest in time period (there might be a few days difference between Michiru's and hers).

This is a phenominal story, and deserves to be read. Thing is, I'm not sure how one could continue afterwards. This alone makes me wonder if Fruit was supposed to be a standalone title, but it became so popular they put out two sequels. At least two of the routes are ill-suited for sequels simply because of how far into the future they go. Anyway, just a slight issue.

Side note: This VN, like Katawa Shoujo does not have a "True" Route. So, whichever you like most, can be the "True" route for you... at least unless the sequels change that...

在具体讨论之前，我想先声明一点：接触《FG》之前，我听闻大家对这款游戏的评价相当之高，比如“神作”，“3A Galgame”。这导致我在游玩之前对这个游戏产生了很高的期待，所以之后内容是基于我心中一个较高的标准来点评的，并不是以随便玩玩的心态来评价的。我之所以点明这点，是希望读者朋友不要认为我只是一味的“喷”这款游戏，也能更好理解我之后的内容。
　　由于《FG》和我之前评测的Galgame有些不同，我想以两个方面以及一个总结来点评它的Story：1. 有关剧情整体的结构安排、故事节奏感的问题为一个方面；2. 每个角色各自的故事为第二个方面；3. 故事总体上的点评为一个总结。
　　一、有关剧情整体的结构安排、故事节奏感的讨论
　　首先我要讨论的是有关剧情整体的结构安排问题，之所以要单独把这个问题提出来讨论是因为《FG》的共通线实在是太长了！借用Steam上一篇英文评测的说法：“The common route is LOOOONG, I mean 5-6+ hours alone long if you canstand watching it[4].（共通线实在是太TM长了，我的意思是你要花5-6个小时通关共通线，前提是你能看得下去。）”5-6小时是你英语特别6的情况下，共通线我一个单词一个单词查着看的，一共看了20+ hours，打对折也要10小时左右。。。而且这个共通线的内容也实在是恶心，几乎全是日常日常日常（重要的事情要说三遍）。我可以用一个公式来总结共通线的故事结构：开篇交代故事背景+无尽的日常+4-5个选项=共通线。我觉得这样做不大理想，至于为什么，这要结合之后每个角色的故事结构来说明。
　　关于各个角色支线的故事结构，我同样也可以用一个公式来总结：前期（日常+伏笔）+中期（各种回忆杀）+后期（男主以爱的名义解决各种“疑难杂症”）。这样的故事结构安排（共通线+支线）会造成这样一种效果：故事前期特别无聊并导致共通线故事拖泥带水，基本毫无看点。而且这也会对后续剧情的展开及其发展造成了不便——磨光了读者的热情。（举个例子：你准备看一个很有剧情的动漫，但看了前4-5集发现除去交代了故事背景就只剩日常了。不是说好要讲故事吗？怎么还没开始？到底还讲不讲额？这时候我相信有不少人要么弃坑，要么以后再说了吧。）
　　二、每个角色各自的故事
　　Sakaki route（榊由美子线）
　　Sachi route（小岭幸线）
　　Makina route（入巢莳菜线）
　　Michuru route（松岛满线）
　　Amane route（周防天音线）
　　这个部分给我的感觉是：故事叙述重点是在Amane和Kazuki这两位人物身上，而没有在事故本身的残酷性上。这样也没什么不可以，只是整个故事在内涵上的表现力就下降了一个档次。至于后面遭遇复仇者的剧情，本身也不复杂，最后结局依旧表现的是男女主角的爱。
　　三、故事的总体评价
　　以上说了这么多整体的故事结构以及各个角色的剧情安排，那么让我来总评一下《FG》的Story吧：《FG》5线的故事内容可用这么一句话来总结：“幸福的妹纸都是相似的，不幸的妹纸各有各的不幸。”她们各有各的不幸，各有各的悲伤，但各有各的幸福。总的来说，如果你是抱着平常心来玩着部Galgame，其素质还是很不错的，各方面都有不错的表现。因其游戏本身故事结构的安排——共通线无尽的日常，支线开头基本还是有日常，这造成我对角色自身的感情早已荡然无存。而且就剧情角度上来说，故事本身也没有什么独具匠心的内容，也没有什么特别发人深省的情节（如果你文学阅历很多，那么看到前期就能把后面的内容猜得八九不离十）。所以《FG》在我心中还远达不到“神作”的水平，但它作为较高水准的Galgame还是很值得人肯定的。我之所以没有给《FG》Story非常高的分数，道理就在这里。
　　并且可以把《FG》和《IMH》进行对比，其一：在共通线上，《IMH》做得比《FG》好，虽然《IMH》共通线也很长，其中的日常也比较冗杂，但它好歹有一条故事主线，即glider和Morning-glory[5]。但《FG》的共通线相对而言略显无聊，也没有为后续故事打好伏笔；其二：在每个角色的分支上，《IMH》各个角色的故事完成度远不如《FG》各个角色的故事完成度来得完整且有趣[4]。
　　最后那么假如是我来编排整个故事结构，我又会怎么做呢？我认为可以适当精简共通线，即交代完故事开端后，以较少的日常简单交代一下几位女主角及其初步性格特征。之后进入选择项，决定攻略角色。然后再来加强故事伏笔的交代，加强故事剧情的起伏，并用一个一个的铺垫或故事来衬托角色性格及其作者想要表达的内容，而不是用无尽的日常来衬托角色性格，这种做法也不是不可以，只是不是很高明而已。这好比，每个角色的一个个故事就像一个个拼图，作者用这些“拼图”在读者面前把这个人物完整地表现出来。每个拼图都是有关联性的，否则我们无法看到整幅拼图的全貌。同样，以日常为主的“拼图”之间的联系远远不及由一个个故事串联起来的“拼图”来得好，太多“日常拼图”拼出来的故事是比较支离破碎的，而由“故事拼图”拼出来的故事是比较完整且有连贯性的。

I wasn't sure what I was expecting from this visual novel; I bought it on a whim based off of the trailer.  And, well, it blew any ideas I've had about what a visual novel could do straight out of the water.

I picked routes in order of who I thought were the most interesting characters; ironically enough, that led me to play through the story in probably the best way possible. 

So if you're looking to buy this game, do it like so:  Yumiko, Michiru, Sachi, Amane, Makina.  It's probably the best way to do it.  There are lots of Amane references in Makina's route, for example, so it's best to do hers first.  And so on, and so forth.

Firstly; this VN is so massive that it has replay value.  Immediately after finishing the last route I intend to go through the whole thing again in order to see how intimiate knowledge of the characters affects their behavior.  I'm a particularly fast reader; gameplay times will vary between players, but you can expect anywhere between 35-80 hours of raw content, depending on how you read.  There's definitely enough content in here to make it worth it.

I purchased this game when it had a 50% off sale; however, after playing this through I can confidently say that I wouldn't regret purchasing it for its full value, or perhaps even double its full value.  This VN is that good.  

What sets this VN apart from others, though?  One of the largest complaints of the story is how long the common is.  To some this is a positive, and others a negative; personally, I don't think a shorter common route would have benefitted the story in the slightest.  Not only does it effectively set a cheerful setting, it allows for a reasonable amount of time to get to know the girls on a superficial level; that way, you're not at all rushed when the time comes to actually select your route.  And, moreover, the choices to enter these routes are pretty obvious; you won't accidentally find yourself on a route unless you pick with your eyes closed, and FoG has a system that allows you to flip back to an option, anyways.  

The common route succeeds in everything it's designed to do; frankly, I have no complaints with it at all.  This isn't something that you can or should settle in a single sitting; I spent one day on the common route, and one day on each of the girl's routes, but that's probably not a time commitment everyone can make.  

So, yeah.  It might take you several sittings to get through the common route.  The VN helpfully splits things pretty neatly with time/location transition screens, so you can do a few days of the common route at a time before stopping to take a break.  

The individual routes...well...they vary from ridiculous levels of heartwarming to crushing despair.  Each and every route is a ridiculous rollercoaster of emotion.  So many themes are explored across all five routes; humanity, survival, love, family, sanity, to name some of the more prevalent ones.  

The protagonist immediately attracted my attention.  You can tell that he's pretty twisted right from the very beginning; it adds to much of the humor and drastically affects the way the plot goes.  This VN dives into complicated subjects with varying detail; from reading this VN I've learned a good exercise program and how to survive an impending bomb blast, amongst other things.  Expect adult situations and violence frequently; this story dives hellishly deep into exploring survival and humanity and becomes impossible to take lightly.  This story is extremely heavy on character development and oftentime the plot intertwines with the exploration of both the protagonist and the character of the route; all of it is done extremely well.  

The plots for all routes are done incredibly well; certain things require a little bit of suspension of disbelief, but as far as I'm concerned they don't detract too much from the story.  And, of course, the characterization is extremely solid for every character involved.

This story is meaningful and poignant.  I unashamedly cried several times reading through it.  There are other VNs in my inventory that still require exploration, but I don't think that they'll come even close to the tragic and heartwarming story that is the Fruit of Grisaia. 

The music and art are both excellent; there are quite a few memorable tracks and the CG collection is excellent; including the SDs and H-scenes (You'll need a patch for those; it is worth it.) there are over 500 CGs in the VN.  The art in the VN is the best that I have seen in any VN to date and the music is up there.  

This VN also has narration for the girls in Japanese; I personally kept them on for the most part, but I'm sure that it doesn't appeal to everyone.  Use at your own discretion.  

Humor, despair, and heartwarming; this VN will not disappoint (honestly, most of the negative reviews are requests for the 18+ patch...).  Even if you're not a genre fan, I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing this VN.

The Grisaia Trilogy, as a whole, is such an example, and for the most part, it’s one that’s been handled very well across the board. Sekai Project, the US publisher for the game, launched a Kickstarter for the trilogy, and while some games that have been funded that way have taken more than a year to see any sort of release, Sekai wasted no time getting the first game, The Fruit of Grisaia, out into the market while there was still some hype behind it. Not only that, with the anime already simulcasting over at Crunchyroll, there almost isn’t a better time to get the game out into the waiting hands of its backers and fans, frankly. Of course, a rushed product would only hurt the project going forward, but for those who are afraid of such a thing, let me reassure you up-front: The Fruit of Grisaia is an amazingly high-quality piece of work, from start to finish, and its translation is pretty damn good across the board. The Fruit of Grisaia ist wahrscheinlich einer der Referenztitel, wenn es um Virtual Novels geht.
Warum dies völlig berechtigt ist und inwiefern mich das Spiel überzeugen konnte, möchte ich im Folgenden erläutern.
Allein schon vom Umfang stellt die anderen Konkurrenten auf Steam in den Schatten. 
Bis man jedes Ende einmal gesehen hat, vergehen ohne Probleme mehr als 60 Stunden. 
An manchen Stellen wurde es etwas zäh, an anderen wiederum so spannend und emotional 
wie es nur wenige Spiele heutzutage schaffen.
Das ist aus meiner Sicht einer der großen Stärken der größeren Visual Novels: 
Eben weil sie sich soviel Zeit für Charakterentwicklung und Details nehmen, 
wachsen sie dem Spieler umso mehr ans Herz.
Und umso heftiger enden die Handlungsstränge dann auch, sowohl positiv als auch negativ.
Wenn ich darauf zurückblicke, muss ich sagen, dass ich es weniger als Spiel sondern eher, wie der Name vielleicht schon
sagt, als eine Art virtuellen Roman bzw. als einen Anime mit Untertiteln bezeichnen würde, 
da wir lediglich durch Entscheidungen beeinflussen können, wie es weitergeht.
An der Stelle möchte ich noch anmerken, dass es sich nicht um die ungeschnittene, ursprüngliche Version des Spiels handelt, sondern um einen PSP-Port, der bereits geschnitten wurde, aber dafür um einige neue Szenen erweitert wurde.
Meiner Meinung nach stört aber das Fehlen dieser expliziten Szenen den Spielverlauf nicht wirklich.
Ein wenig schade für manche dürfte die Tatsache sein, dass es weder deutsche Untertitel noch eine deutsche Sprachausgabe gibt. Um ehrlich zu sein, bin ich aber auch froh darüber, denn hier habe ich gemerkt, wie schwierig es sein würde, die verschiedenen Charaktere in einer deutschen Lokalisierung angemessen darzustellen, ohne dass sie etwas von ihrem Charme
verlieren würden. Insgesamt ist die Vertonung aber sehr gut gelungen, wozu u.a. auch der Soundtrack zählt.
Zugegeben, manche Stimmen fangen nach einiger Zeit schon an, zu nerven. An der Stelle empfehle ich einfach eine Pause
einzulegen und später weiterzumachen. 
Hinsichtlich der Grafik gibt es nichts zu kritisieren. Diese mag sicherlich nicht jedermanns Geschmack sein, doch objektiv
betrachtet sind Charakter-und Hintergrundtexturen stimmig und fügen sich gut in das Gesamtbild ein. 
Des Weiteren gibt uns das Spiel zahlreiche Optionen, um unser Spielerlebnis anzupassen.

Alles in allem ist The Fruit of Grisaia bisher mein Favorit unter den Visual Novels, der seinem Preis im Vergleich zu manch
anderen Geschichten auf Steam absolut gerecht wird, und ich kann es allen ans Herz legen, die keinen Groll gegen diese 
Art von Spiel hegen.
Ich bin gespannt, wie die Geschichte um Kazami Yuuji und seiner Klassenkameraden in den nächsten beiden Teilen weitergehen wird.

I had initially left a preliminary review after finishing a single path. This is an update after having finished the entire game. All five paths, all ten endings.
Having done that, I've gotta say. Holy shit, that was an incredible experience. Maybe, my expectations (tempered by the likes of Sakura Swim Club...ugh) had an effect on this, but... I literally ended up dropping everything else I was playing on PC at the time just to consume more of these narratives. I know that the localization of The Labyrinth of Grisaia is in progress and I'm very much excited for when it will come out.

Pros: 
-Since this is a VN, let's get the most important bit out of the way first. The writing in this game, while it takes it a bit to get started, is absolutely PHENOMENAL. Each of the character arcs is handled incredibly well. Each of the five characters are thought through and are very interesting character studies. Not to mention, the way the character personalities clash is often hilarious. It's to the extent that I've found myself contemplating some plot points or speculating about possible upcoming events while at work or on my commute.
-On the note of writing, I've gotta give major props to the writers that handled the translation. The amount of vocabulary that I've learned from this game exceeds most natively english titles. There were even times when I saw a word, thought it was a typo, looked it up, and learned that it was an actual word. Well done. 
-This game doesn't fall into the pit trap of having copy/pasted narratives. Yes, there's some similar themes that happen on occasion, but I was pleased to see that each of the paths is basically unique and even each of the endings is distinctly different. 
-The voice actors have done an excellent job. While I, no longer, speak Japanese, but the emotion, intonation, and delivery have left me often just letting the VA finish the particular line before advancing to the next bit....and, that doesn't happen often, as I'm usually speeding through dialogue, not bothering to wait on the VA.
-The music, while I feel that some of the loops could have been handled a bit better, otherwise, I have no complaints. Each individual track is fantastic, been pleasant enough to listen to, and I don't recall any of them having become grating, even after a multitude of repetitions.
-The art in the game is superb. I won't even deny that a handful of scenes have made their way into my wallpapers collection.
-Unexpectedly enough, there's also quite the collection of bonus material. I know that VNs commonly include their art and a few other things with them, but this is even more generous.

A couple of other comments, though they are not exactly cons:
-The way each of the routes is set up, once you branch off, what happened in the other route no longer exists. As a result of that, there were points where I couldn't help but feel a bit guilty choosing one option, knowing that I've avandoned the fate of a character in favor of another. That being said, I believe that this VN's character progressions would have suffered quite a bit if it was a "help everyone" type of story, so I'm not really complaining. Hell, it's not often that a narrative has left me to care this much for a character.
-I've gotta mention the censorship. I've gotta give credit to Frontwing to having included additional content in the M-rated version to make up for the cut scenes, but... It does (apparently) have an effect on one of the character arcs and it's the matter of personal principle to note this. I suppose, at least, that's easily enough remedied if you desire to do so.

TL;DR: All in all, though, it's been a marvelous and enjoyable experience (to the point of considering this to be the best VN I've consumed to date). I know that the $40 pricetag may seen intimidating, but if it'll help, I'll say this much. The first story arc I complete was Sachi's. In my opinion, even if the game had ended with just that, I'd still consider this to have been money well spent. I'm very much excited for the sequel to be released.

[h1]One of the better Visual Novel currently available on Steam[/h1]

When looking for good Visual Novels, Steam is unfortunately often not the right place. Most of the VNs available there are rather geared towards heavy fan-service (not to say Grisaia has none) and usually aren't really good overall when compared to other ones - as can be seen from their score on VNDB (Visual Novel Database).

That being said Grisaia is one of the few exception, hopefully soon to be joined by Muv Luv as well. The story is entertaining, you easily get attached to the characters and for once the protagonist isn't your typical blank canvas - if anything he is very un-japanese in his behavior, which is a breath of fresh air in a Visual Novel. 

For those who don't know what a Visual Novel is, it's fairly simple. Just imagine reading a book, with images and music to set the mood and atmosphere. On top of that, sprinkle a few choices you can make as a reader to turn the story towards what you want it to become. Note that in most Visual Novels, different routes are drastically different from one another (it isn't an "illusion of choice" like in The Walking Dead for instance).

Grisaia has no 'true ending' per se, and each route (5 of them) all have their own story attached to it. If one of the character doesn't interest you, there is no need to read her route. Just choose what you want to see, and enjoy the story.

Note: For those worried about the H-content being removed from the Steam version, I only played this version of Grisaia and didn't feel like anything was 'missing' - the story still flowed fairly naturally, and you still get plenty of lewd jokes (Amane, Sachi, please...). However, if you are really adamant about playing the original version, than Steam might not be the right place. 

Have fun reading!

To sum everything up, I enjoyed this game 100%, but before I go into detail about the game I should make a note that for the people playing a visual novel for the first time, you shouldn't expect much "gameplay" from this game. Yes, there are choices but they are very few compared to other choice-based storytelling games, you should expect to read a lot of throughout the game. Expecting otherwise will probably leave you disappointed, if you don't like reading you should turn back, because The Fruit of Grisaia has A LOT of reading. It's admittedly a different experience from reading a book (the BGM, voices, and illustrations help guide you on the atmosphere and the appearances/emotions of the characters rather than just leaving it up to your imagination), but you shouldn't buy this game if you hate reading.

* (If you don't want to read the long paragraphs of text you can skip to the short paragraph at the end for a summary)
____

Moving on, The Fruit of Grisaia is a standard visual novel, with choices that lead you to different routes that each focus on six different heroines. It's pretty lengthy and depending on your reading speed, it will probably take you somewhere around 60-85 hours to go through everything. Despite it's length however, there's a great attention to detail throughout Grisaia. An off-hand remark in one route becomes something the character actually does in another route, and the storywriters took great care in interwining each route indirectly with each other. The other thing is that all of the main heroines in Grisaia have background and purpose behind their characters. What might seem like a silly anime trope has a deeper and perhaps darker backstory behind it.

Even if the characters started out as simple archetypes, they sure don't now. Everything the characters do has some explained reasoning for it, and again you can see that the writers took a lot of careful detail in weaving the character's backstory with their personality and actions.  And again, despite the fact that there's thousands upon thousands of lines of text, the story for each route is quite diverse. I was surprised at how the seriousness and setting could change within each route, and it's nice to see that the routes for each heroine have their own little slice at all the different atmospheres and backgrounds a story can possess. The other thing I enjoyed was the fact that throughout learning each heroine's backstory, you also learn more about the past of the main character, Yuuji, and his personality as well.

It's something of an intricate puzzle piece, where all the different parts of Yuuji's past and personality connect across all routes, and over the course of the game you learn more and more about him. In addition to the diverse storytelling is that the writers of the story aren't afraid to pull their punches. Each route has a bad and a good ending, and even though you know that there's a better alternative ending, you can't help but be surprised, or even disturbed about the endings that just happened. Some of them can be absolutely brutal, and others can be lighter and less emotional.

____
* Short Version

To put it all succinctly, the Fruit of Grisaia is an absolutely enthralling and intersting visual novel with a diverse set of characters and storytelling and prose that is enrapturing in it's own way. The writing isn't afraid to hit you with a few punches, and the amount of detail that goes into crafting each route and character is amazing to say the least. This game is fantastic, and is worth every penny (for me at least). 


If you're on the fence about whether or not you'll enjoy the game, you may want to watch a couple episodes of the anime adapation (I wouldn't watch more than 3, otherwise you'll be spoiled a bit) which will help you get a feel for the writing style of the game. It doesn't really showcase everything, but it should give you an idea of whether or not you'll enjoy the game (but don't judge the game solely by the anime, it doesn't really do the VN justice). If you have watched the anime before and enjoyed it, buy this as well. The anime doesn't really do the game complete justice, and although I watched the anime prior to playing the VN, I still found myself surprised at the turns the story took.

I'm going to start off by saying that I have always hated Visual Novels. Keep this in mind as you read my review. This is going to be as spoiler free as I can make it.

The Fruit of Grisaia (Grisaia no Kajitsu) is more or less a picture book about a battle-hardened child soldier attempting to return to a normal life. I'm sure most people are thinking the same thing I was, "If I wanted to spend $30 on a book, I'd want a physical copy and it better be good." Well, while the former isn't possible, the latter is completely true. VN games always turned me off, before; lack of action, lack of many choices, pure focus on story, lots of reasons that I'm sure many people share. Despite all the reasons for not wanting this game, I found myself returning to the store page every now and then. I finally managed to grab it for around $12, and I feel like I ripped off the developer. This game is well worth the full price, and probably over. Just about every character, no matter how minor a part they play, has a personality. You either hate a character, like a character, or love a character - and not always for good reasons. The 5 classmates - Yumiko, Makina, Amane, Sachi, and Michiru - are all perfectly unique. There's almost no "copy/paste" idea present. The interactions between characters seem extremely natural, as well. I refrained from writing a review until I had finished every route the game had(other than the bad routes), and I found it harder and harder to do that as I progressed. Despite the circumstances of each of the characters, you can relate to every single one of them. I often found myself caught off guard when a character said "Yuuji", because I was so engrossed in the story that I had actually assumed the role of the main character. The replay value is pretty decent, as well. I'd love to travel through this story once more. The scenes often invoke emotions you can't imagine; I laughed at the most ridiculous things, I cried when things happened, I even felt myself worrying about the characters. By playing through the dating routes, I realized a common theme is that none of the bad stuff would've happened if Yuuji(you) hadn't showed up or made the choice to interfere. That caused a feeling of hopelessness and self-doubt in me, as well. That being said, I highly recommend playing through every girl's route. You learn more about not only the girls, but Yuuji as well. As you learn more about the circumstances for each girl being there, you learn about Yuuji's own past; a past he keeps hidden away. If you don't find the emotional aspect convincing enough, this game teaches practical knowledge, as well. I learned self-defense techniques, how to deal with women, and survival and cooking skills, to name a few. I can't remember the last time I learned something I could use in everyday life from a video game, aside from a profound lesson on human nature or a phylisophical idea. I'm currently letting my little brother play through himself, and he is the typical "COD AKSHUN POW POW GUN FIRE GIT GUD SKRUB" gamer. He loves it so much I had to threaten to take the computer away in order to write this review. I also plan on buying a couple copies for my close friends, and sharing this experience with them. I have fallen in love with this game, and it has sparked an interest within me for other VN's. If you see a Visual Novel in my library, it's because of Fruit of Grisaia.

TL;DR: 10/10 Would buy full price. Get this game. Even if you hate VN's.

I played this game back before it was on steam and loved it then, so seeing it brought to steam made me squeal with joy. So let's get this review going. This game is a "Visual Novel," meaning that there's really nothing in the gameplay department apart from making a few choices at certain plot-relevant crossroads, but gameplay isn't what we're here for, this genre is all about the story, so what sets this apart from others in the genre? (list of differences to the non-steam version at the end)

The first thing that catches my eye is that instead of a bland, everyman, blank-slate protagonist like a large portion of visual novels, we get Kazami Yuuji, an unsociable, military-raised teenager not so different from Sagara Sousuke (for anyone who has watched Full Metal Panic). Yuuji is blunt and a bit bad with handling personal relationships, but I honestly have to say that he's a great guy; he is incredibly capable and very rarely does anything negative without a good reason. Our supporting characters are also very unique and each play off of Yuuji and each other in very entertaining ways (though I will freely admit that Makina can get on my nerves). Here's a quick overview of the other students while keeping spoilers to a minimum (skip a paragraph if you don't want to see):
Makina: Girl with stunted growth and childish tendancies. Ends up picking up a lot of bad habits and harsh language from Amane and Yuuji.
Amane: Well-developed body and lots of erotic teasing made towards Yuuji. Very maternal and watches over Makina carefully. Also seems to want to take care of the socially-hopeless Yuuji.
Michiru: Girl who is outright stated to be purposefully attempting to fall into the "Tsundere" archetype, but more often than not ends up looking like nothing more than a contrarian idiot who's the butt of most of the jokes around the dorm.
Sachi: Highly devoted girl who will listen to any order given to her. Often goes around wearing a maid uniform do to an offhand comment about it suiting her getting mistaken as an order (not an uncommon occurence). Has some obvious issues with common sense and flexible thinking.
Yumiko: Aloof and introverted, but has some violent tendancies when annoyed or threatened. Despite this, she is probably the most reliable of the group for tough conversations (if you exclude Yuuji since we're kind of playing as him)

The aforementioned choices in the game will lead you down the character arcs of different heroines depending on what you choose, though this game makes it pretty easy to get to your favorite heroine since there are very few choices in the game and the ones that actually matter are essentially "Go down this girl's route right now or continue the main route until we give you another choice." Ostensibly, each girl has one more choice leading you to the bad end or the good end, though I'll be honest and say that I can't agree that every girl's endings split into those two categories [spoiler]more specifically, one girl's endings would be better described as bad/worse while another has good/better[/spoiler]. Every heroine (Yuuji as well) has some sort of emotional baggage holding them down which got them put into this school to begin with; needless to say, if you go into a route and get details about these incidents, you can get drawn into some seriously heart-wrenching moments of fear, depression, desparation, and rejection as you relive the most painful moments of someone's past.

Having just replayed the Matsushima Michiru route in celebration of getting my hands on the steam release, I will freely admit I was brought to tears multiple times despite knowing everything that was going to be said, and this girl's route probably wouldn't be considered heaviest of the tragedies presented here (though, paraphrasing some words from the game, "You can't really compare two tragedies to each other," so I feel a bit bad trying to order the routes by tragic-ness). I look forward to replaying my favorite two routes next. As a side note, knowing the characters issues in advance actually explains a few strange moments that I hadn't noticed the first time around, so the replay was quite worth it.

As promised, I will list out the differences I've noticed between this and the non-steam release. First off, this is absolutely the exact same translation that was provided in the original version (not that this will surprise anyone who knows what a pain translating a game can be). Though I noticed that there don't seem to be translation notes popping up in the corners anymore, so either those got removed or I missed the option to toggle them. Also, on the steam page, you might notice some CG that weren't in the original game; there's a fair number of those scattered throughout the game. Anyway, next up, Steam doesn't like erotic content, so the intercourse scenes have been removed. Judging by the routes I've replayed so far, usually this is just taking a hacksaw to the scene, cuting out the part of the game with erotic CG/descriptions, and skipping to the conversation afterward (leaving a very awkward transition), but sometimes they change the scene slightly and toss in a new CG to make the transition slightly less abrupt, turning it into a chaste, heartwarming moment as opposed to a lustful one. There are also some other changes to the non-heroine moments, like a certain flashback scene involving the captain of Amane's old club in middle school being changed to be less suggestive. Some of the other changes: There was some nudity in the original version besides the erotic scenes, such as when some "girl-talk" was happening in the bath, so the character sprites were changed slightly to cover the naughty bits with soap. Also, some scenes got cut in places, but were removed so subtly that I didn't even notice until I went back and looked at a CG set for the original game (Michiru and Sachi building sand...stuff on the beach got drastically shortened, but I didn't even notice until I realized I never saw the CG of Michiru being burid in the sand (This review has ended up mentioning her quite a lot, hasn't it)). This all being said, they kept a very large amount of content in the game. For example, stuff like Amane standing around in Yuuji's room in her underwear ended up making it passed the censor stick, and if that made it by unscathed, I highly doubt they made many big cuts besides the one beach scene that I happened to remember.

Conclusion: Hilarious characters, engaging story, and fun to replay despite (and/or because of) knowing the plot. Easily a massive thumbs up from me. I really want to play the two sequel games, but the complicated language used in this game is making my doubt my Japanese is fluent enough for the task, so I might have to wait until the others get translated...that or watch the anime versions for the condensed story.

     The Fruit of Grisaia is the first of the Grisaia Trilogy. After that, I watched the anime hoping to grasp clearly what the fuss was about. I enjoyed what I saw, but I felt like too much was missing from the original novel. I wanted more.

Two endings in (Michiru and Yumiko), and I have realized how gravely I had underscored this novel.

From tackling powerful topics, such as depression and suicide, and giving each character a truly memorable personality, Grisaia no Kajitsu is without a doubt an experience unlike any other. The ways that each character embrace their "unusual" circumstances are worthy of earnest praise and commendation, and every victory and defeat that affects them affects the player just as much.

Some people will equate this game as simply another eroge in the market and will lament that this is "the censored shell of the original", but perhaps it is because of the removal of the h-scenes that allows one to appreciate the story behind those acts of affection. The Fruit of Grisaia is an experience like no other. Time and again, I have been truly awed by the thoughtfulness of the plot behind each route, and the execution of the plot to make almost every action feel unquestionably real (even though sometimes the "actions" done are beyond reality. 一部可以称得上是GALGAME中3A大作的游戏。作为FrontWing社的十周年纪念作品，《灰色的果实》获得了2011年美少女游戏赏（If My Heart Had Wings获得了2012年的金奖）的金奖，并且有着不俗的销量。《灰色的迷宫》以及《灰色的乐园》为《灰色的果实》的续作。
没接触之前以为是一部普通的校园恋爱galgame，结果故事一开始就有点神展开的迹象。个人认为这是一个值得一玩的剧情向系列，虽然和普通galgame一样可以攻略不同的妹子OOXX，但是剧情挺有意思。

前段时间有改编TV动画，制作良心，画质很凶残，全程宽幅画面搞得我一开始以为是剧场版动画。如果想对剧情有个大致了解的可以去看看动画版，动画版修改和简化了大量原作游戏的剧情，所以不会太多影响到游戏的体验。

因为LZ只玩过《灰色的果实》，另外两部作品没有汉化和英化，所以下面的介绍和评测均针对《灰色的果实》。

[b]画面[/b]
渡边明夫 负责的人物设定，他负责了《化物语》动画版的人设以及作画监督，各位是否觉得由美子 和 战场原 有一些相像呢？

原画则是由渡边明夫 和 フミオ 共同负责。
フミオ 曾负责了CLANNAD后传——《智代After ～It's a Wonderful Life～》的人设和原画。
有看到部分朋友反映说人物立绘有些崩？我倒是没注意到，个人觉得画面从各方面来说都很不错。

游戏中有用到不少Q版二头身CG来表现一些卖萌向的轻松插曲，挺有意思。
Q版的SD原画是ななかまい 负责的，某些绅士朋友经常挂在嘴边的《妹调X教日记》的原画担当。

[b]配音[/b]
主要声优有田口宏子 （代表作《悠久之翼》的 宫子）
田中凉子 （代表作《LittleBusters!》的 来谷唯湖）
鸣海エリカ （代表作《公主恋人》的 希尔维娅（长得像saber的那个））
民安智惠 （代表作《LittleBusters!》的 枣铃）
水桥香织 （代表作《零之轨迹》的 缇欧）
清水爱 （代表作《少女骑士物语》的 希咲美樱）
可以看出，本作的声优阵容很强大，加上渡边明夫，Front Wing社对这部作品也是下血本了。
配乐方面主要是由菊田大介 和 桑岛由一 负责，游戏的BGM与几首ED都挺不错，但是算不上印象深刻。
主题曲演唱者为日本的著名女歌手飞兰 ，我知道 飞兰 是因为一首出自TV动画《食灵零》（LZ当年最喜欢的作品之一，推荐大家一看）的插曲——《Reincarnation》。

[b]剧情[/b]
男主角转学到了一个特殊的学校——美浜学园，这是一个只有六名学生的学校。包括男主在内，总共只有7个人的美浜学园为何而创立？学园的背后又隐藏着怎么样的秘密？包括男主在内，这6名学生又是为何会来到这个特殊的学园？
光看剧情简介，可能会有朋友认为这是一部6个主人公在学校里互相厮杀的作品。在这里，我想说明的是这部作品并不存在几个主人公互相厮杀的死亡游戏情节，也不是一部像《寒蝉》那样的猎奇悬疑向游戏。

虽说是黑历史，不过除了天音 有经历过“大逃杀”般的黑历史外，其他几个角色的黑历史说实话真不怎么“黑”。
除了天音 线外，有着大量“鬼X父”情节的 莳菜 线也获得了不少玩家的赞誉。

平心而论，本作的剧情并不算优秀，共通线的日常剧情不错，但是略显拖拉。进入个人线后，许多情节显得比较牵强和中二。但是我还是挺喜欢这部作品的，有着黑历史和战斗内容，但是没有《Phantom》那般揪心与沉重；有着卖萌的轻松日常，而故事却不是没起伏的白开水。游戏时会比较专注，打通后又不会感觉惆怅或者放不下，作为一部娱乐轻松用的游戏来说，这不是正好吗？


本作的OOXX内容很多，应该是steam上几部galgame里最多的了吧（《福音公主》不知道能否一战，过会去看看CG包），男主身经百战（各方面来说），人物立绘和普通CG里也有露X点的画面。按照代理商的做法，应该会和X猫游戏一样，将这些OOXX内容完全删去，之前在绿光页面的评论里，已经有骚年开始作死发OOXX版了，或许不久又会掀起新一轮OOXX补丁风波。
